snippet: With fewer providers competing aggressively for health care business, doctors who sell their practices are feeling pressed to meet financial targets.
abstract: Doctors in Boise, Idaho, complain consolidation of the medical industry has given two hospitals too much power over the medical pipeline, allowing them to dictate which tests and procedures to perform, and how much to charge; issue reflects national problem, as doctors who have sold their practices and signed contracts with hospitals report growing pressure to meet financial goals at expense of quality care.

byline.original: By JULIE CRESWELL and REED ABELSON

lead_paragraph: With fewer providers competing aggressively for health care business, doctors who sell their practices are feeling pressed to meet financial targets.

headline.seo: Doctors Who Work for Hospitals Face a New Bottom Line
headline.main: A Hospital War Reflects a Bind for  Doctors in the U.S.
headline.print_headline: A Hospital War Reflects A Bind for U.S. Doctors

keywords.value: St Alphonsus Regional Medical Center (Boise, Idaho)
keywords.name: organizations
